text:
We went to Pondok Pitaya restaurant to eat multiple times during our stay in Balian, it has a relaxed vibe, awesome place to watch the surfing from right on the beach.

The food was good and the service staff all super helpful with amazing English. This was really helpful for me as a coeliac as I was easily able to order and ask for no soy sauce/ kecap manis/ chicken stock powder with no issues, which is not usually the case in Bali!

For coeliacs travelling to Balian- it was easier to eat here than I expected despite no reviews for gluten free food anywhere in Balian which nearly stopped us coming. So glad we came!

I brought my own gf soy sauce and kecap manis to Pondok Pitaya and ordered Nasi goreng and also pork sambal Mayah without any soy/kecap manis, then just added my own. Also had poached eggs with homemade potato roesti, bacon and spinach which was delicious. Be aware they do fry other breaded and battered foods in the fryer though, I'm asymptomatic so I decided to chance it. They also have smoothie bowls which look yum.

The frozen margaritas were good too, and not too sweet! Partner loved the breakfast and all the Indonesian dishes he had, and said the coffee was decent (for Bali!)

text:
So happy we decided to visit Balian Beach and stay at Pondok Pitaya!  Fair warning that it is a trek from the airport - traffic meant that we had a 3 hour drive - but so worth it once you are there.  

The hotel staff coordinated our transport for us, and kept the kitchen open so that we could eat when we arrived after our long drive.  Breakfast was great, although it would be amazing if it could start at 7 am.  The food was fantastic - my husband and I are still talking about the pork belly bowl.  And, my 6 y/o daughter loved the popsicles (natural, local fresh fruit, small size) - I think she ate 3 per day.

Our room was clean with good amenities and very quiet.  The pool was great - cleaned every morning and a great view of the beach.  

We did the waterfall hike one day, which we really enjoyed.  There weren't any of the typical tourist spots that we were forced to go to - just a 1 hour drive past beautiful scenery (lots of real rice fields and wild jungle), a nice hike to the waterfall, as much time to swim as we wanted, and then lunch at a fantastic warung that was locals-only.  We could decide when we wanted to head back to the hotel and made it back for an afternoon in the ocean.

This spot is about the beach!  There isn't a lot nearby.  We did walk around the small village - we did sunset drinks as a nearby restaurant and visited the local temple.  The rest of the area is just local families.

For anyone that is looking for a real Bali experience, I would recommend Balian Beach and Pondok Pitaya.

The staff was amaze-balls. We had one woman who was sick the first night, so the manager asked a driver to stay overnight, ready to escort her to the hospital, just in case. Seriously, above and beyond. 

The black sand beaches were dramatic, clean and beautiful, and the surfing was awesome. Pipes to the right and left--at the edge of a river delta, so typically good surfing. Clean bottoms where we were (tumbling rocks but no coral). 

The pool was great. Nice temp. Tons of places to sit and sun. Clean and refreshing. 

Yoga shala: clean, gorgeous view, quiet and peaceful, with stereo surround sound for our music compilations. Mats and blocks were provided, too, which was nice for those of us who either forgot or didn't bring mats. Classes offered on-site 2x/day. 

In all, I couldn't have asked for more or for a better experience. Highly recommend (in case you couldn't tell).

text:
We stayed at the Pondok Pitaya for 5 nights. The hotel has a Balinese feel and is located right on the beach at the end of a road that runs through the local village. A local river also runs into the sea adjacent to the hotel. Balian is very quiet and being a rural area, has no 'nightlife' or shops.  If you're not into surfing or yoga, bring a good book ........ or perhaps several - and it can be a very relaxing holiday.
Balian is approximately 2 hours up the west coast from Legian. It is primarily a surfing spot and this hotel has tended to cater for that market through comfortable but basic rooms for surfers. However it appears to be attempting to expand its appeal and now also has more comfortable accommodation behind the basic beachfront units. We stayed in this newer accommodation (known as the 'River Suites'). There are Ground and First Floor Levels - and they've been constructed of timber recycled from old fishing boats. It's a clever bit of eco-friendly building work and looks great. Ensuites come with each room and these are open air with privacy walls. Our room was large and airy with good ventilation and A/C if required. No fridge or kettle is provided.
Yoga is held in the morning and afternoon at the hotel. The classes are conducted in a pavilion in the middle of the well maintained gardens adjacent to the beach. 
The hotel has a cafe and bar area and the food is quite good and not expensive. Breakfast was included in our tariff and we had a set choice of a 'Healthy', 'Local' or 'Western' breakfast. We had the 'Healthy' each morning and it was fresh and enjoyable.  The hotel also has an attractive pool area and sun lounges adjacent to the beach.
The staff were very friendly and helpful.
Across the road from the hotel and overlooking the beach is the cafe, 'Sushi Surf'. Good sushi; not expensive and a great view of the surf. 
Just up the hill about 50 metres from 'Sushi Surf' is the more traditional 'Deki's Warung'. Good local food at very reasonable prices in a friendly casual atmosphere - and again, with a great view of the surf.
The costs were reasonable and I'm happy to recommend this hotel if you're going to Balian.

text:
Firstly let me say this is the second year in a row I have spent a week here with my family (wife and kids aged 3,7,9). I would return to Balian and stay here again, but ONLY for the location. The hotel and service could be significantly improved, especially given the price you pay.

For Balian, the accommodation is massively overpriced, you can easily stay almost anywhere else for 20-60% of what you pay at Pondok Pitaya and as far as I can tell, you're paying just for the location. 

The buildings (aside from the ugly river suite out the back) are quaint Javanese inspired, but are dark inside with little airflow and they feel dirty. The bathrooms are very rudimentary with industrial valves for taps, no plugs for the basin etc. 

I noticed that since last year they have installed much better mosquito nets over all the beds, perhaps due to the increased incidence of dengue fever in the area. 

The place is overrun with dogs. Personally I love dogs and the ones here are lovely, healthy and friendly so it's a plus for me, but if you don't like dogs, be warned.

The surf break averages 1 shark attack per year so that helps keep the crowds down :). Don't swim or surf after rain as the rivermouth empties lots of disgusting detritus into the ocean and you're likely to end up with hep-a, an ear infection or something worse.

GOOD
The location is amazing. The complex is literally on the beach with the restaurant and pool being just steps from the sand. While not great for swimming or lying around, the black sand beach has a certain beauty to it. The wave is super fun but can get reasonably heavy when it's bigger. The included breakfast is pretty good. The 'Healthy' option has a fruit bowl with yoghurt and a sprinkling of granola with eggs any style  a green juice has been my regular.   Its a great place for kids, very safe, very open and our kids just ganged up with other kids also on holiday and roamed around in tribes from room to pool. If you can tolerate the heat, walks up and down the beach are great, sunsets from the headland by secret cove are also worth the walk. Watch the cloud of bats escape the cave at ~620-630 pm every night. Most of the rooms have a large covered balcony area you can sit on lounge style furniture and watch the surf. This is the main attraction of this place.

There is a large yoga studio which you can use when the classes are not on. I travel with my own matt and prefer my own schedule so didn't attend a class (quite expensive at 125,000Rps), but the space is very nice.

BAD
Wifi is awful. It's almost like they have only one access point for the entire resort. In order to access it you have to be sitting in the restaurant and even then it only seems to be reliable when you sit right by the reception side of the restaurant. Forget about getting wifi in your room. As well as being unreliable, it's also very slow. The staff seem to know this, but the don't really care.

They provide 4x 250ml water bottles per day and charge for refills. I personally travel with my own water bottles and try not to put more plastic into the ocean, but once again, they don't seem to care here. Yes I know that it's standard in Bali to pay for bottled water, but at the price you pay to stay here, they should have a 19l water dispenser bottle in each room.  A 19l water tank costs 15,000Rps at the local store. Filling a 1l bottle at Pondok Pitaya costs 10,000Rps. Just leaves a bad taste in your mouth. I went and bought my own dispenser and put it in my room for 75,000Rps.

Aside from the included breakfast, don't bother with the restaurant. There is no soul, care or love in the food and once again, it's more expensive than anywhere else in Balian. Eat anywhere else. My pick is Deckies Warung a 2min stroll up the hill. Great view, great vibe, great food. Oh and it's 1/2 the price.

The pool could be incredible but instead it's poorly maintained, either overclorinated so it burns your eyes and turns your hair green, or under chlorinated so it gets filthy and slimy. Because the resort is so open, despite they signs saying 'pool only for guests' there are frequently many users of the pool who are not staying here.

They seem to run out of pool towels at about 11am, so don't expect to get one if you're late. Again the staff don't seem to care...'maybe you try this afternoon'.

The beds are awful. If you're a hot sleeper like me, it's bad enough not having air conditioning and minimal airflow, but compounded with a cheap foam mattress it makes for some very hot sleeps. Again for what you are paying here, you should expect a decent mattress. 

It's not all bad. The staff are polite and friendly. Some of them do make an effort, but many are just going through the motions. Despite all the above, we have had a great week here for a second time and if there weren't so many other places to explore, we would come back for a third year :)

text:
Stayed here out of main season and it was pretty quiet, despite the fact that it is literaly right on the beach.  The surf was epic, lefts and rights up to about 8ft.  Didn't really hold any bigger so headed off to Medewi.  Watch the river after rain, can create some nasty rips and bring diown some rubbish.
Pondok is an older style Bali accom, most room dont have aircon, but then ones that do are at the back of the complex in a well landscaped area but with no views.  The beach is not safe to swim, but the pool is great and there is a big grassed area for whatever.  I surfed alot, my wife did yoga alot ,but there is not much else do do or see whithout a tour, a motorbike or rental.  And watch the main road, its chaos, but we were gutted we had to leave.  Food at the Pondok is very good and at a reasonable price for the area, but several options close by so no worries.  Great little vibe, no hassles from trinket or t shirt sellers no surf mafia like at Medewi (very few locals in the surf) and a cleanish sandy beach.  If you like a bit of a getaway spot to chill and surf, then this is it, we will be back for sure.
WIFI signal was poor most of the time

text: We stayed for 4 nights in a river suite. Block A has very firm beds, so we moved to block C, for softer beds, which was no problem. Great location, pool, gardens and buildings, Balinese feeling for sure. Staff friendly. Food great and good sizes. Plenty of other food options also close by. Air con in the river suites was great, although it's a small room, we still fitted 4 boards and luggage in as well. Right in front of the surf it's a top spot. We had some perfect 4ft clean surfs in the morning and afternoons. Can get windy midday which affects quality. 2 weeks before the last shark attack, people also saw a shark fin that followed them in one morning , that sort of spooked us a bit. Then it rained and the water got real dirty, so surfing not recommended, but it didn't seem to stop anyone, we also went out but it's in your mind. When it got big, we surfed medewi lefts, which was about 5-6ft, and super fun, not too heavy, and longer rides. Overall we loved it, but the issue with a shark in dirty water is too be taken seriously.

text:
If you're staying near Balian Beach, this is pretty much your only option for yoga, and it's accessible even if you're not staying at the hotel. Nicky's morning yoga class was of medium intensity good for beginners and intermediate yogis (even those who aren't staying at the Pondok Pitaya villas). He offered lots of options for both an easier and harder practice, and took time at the end of class to teach a sitting vinyasa - using your upper body to go from standing to sitting. I learned a lot from this section and appreciated him taking so much time and care to walk through all the steps with the class.  Plus, it's timing of 10:30 - 12pm is the perfect time to work up a sweat for lunch, which you can grab right next door. It's mediocre, but reasonably priced.

The afternoon class was, frankly, painful. It was 90 minutes of slow stretching with almost no movement. Even though I was sore from surfing, I was bored within the first 30 minutes and struggled to stay focused for the next 60.
title: For yoga, come for the morning, skip the afternoon class

text:
We dropped into the Pondok Pitaya Hotel for the day as we drove up from Canggu where we were staying to check out the surf. 

Location - at Bailan Beach north west in  Bali, approx 1.5hrs drives drive north of Seminyak.  The hotel is located on the beachfront so its perfect for watching the sunset & the waves. 

The hotel is  suited to surfers or those looking for a yoga retreat. 

The beach is lovely but its not really suited to swimmers due to the rocky formation in the shallow waters. 

There is a swimming pool overlooking the ocean. The pool is on the small size but its adequate a little need of attention & renovation is needed. However ; we enjoyed using it to cool off from the hot December sun. 

Yoga was held in a lovely thatched roof building located in the heart of the hotel gardens overlooking the beach. It did look very peaceful. 

The rooms looked extremely cute with recycled timber facade & timber interior. The large separate houses also looked seriously suited to large groups , young surfers or those just looking for space. 

The open outdoor restaurant was excellent & the food tasty & cheap. There are a few other small cafes up the road too. 

Overall - undeveloped region of Bali , if looking for serenity in a beach location with simple tastes & budget then Pondok Pitaya Hotel is ideal for a beach yoga retreat.

text:
I stayed here for one month for an organized event and was impressed with the beautiful location and setting, however extremely disappointed with the state and price of my shared room and the daily buffet. 
The room itself was made of concrete cylinders and the bathroom was always wet and dark. There was no hot water and at one point the shower pipe burst and the remedy was to smother it with more concrete - which didn't work and made for a leaky, squirty wall. It was very dusty and dirty because it's tricky to clean concrete. The linens were always stained and only changed every 4 or so days. The towels either smelled of mothballs or overly perfumed soap. We would put our towels (that we had been using for many days) on the ground near the door to communicate that they were dirty (even leaving a note kindly asking for new ones) and they would be hung back up on the racks again. I stayed in one of the Surfer Suites and saw an enormous contrast between these and the other newer air conditioned rooms. I wish I knew there would have been such a drastic difference in quality for such a small price difference. 
The buffet food was repetitive and just tolerable. We were paying around $35 usd /day for just the food and I was shocked at how minimal it was for the price. We had pumpkin, rice and spinach every meal with the occasional fried chicken, veggie broth and noodles. Our fresh juice was half water. People became very ill a number of times throughout our stay here, including myself. Many of us opted out of eating at the buffet, despite already paying so much for it, and would eat for under 6$ at a high end restaurant up the road. For the type of event it was, healthier, unprocessed, not fried or boiled food would have been majorly appreciated. And variety - Bali is so abundant with many kinds of fresh fruits and vegetables and can easily be washed with clean water through your filter. 
Overall, the event itself was immensely gratifying, the location on the beach was beautiful, the studio was lovely. 
The food wasn't healthy, creative or hygienic. My room wasn't clean, nice or properly attended to. The amount of money paid for these two things (outside of the event) was a real damn bummer.
title: Over priced for room and buffet

text:
I'm 4 months pregnant. My husband and I knew this might be our last chance to holiday before the baby comes. So we wanted it to be special. Destination? (Easy...) Bali. But this time we want to experience the real face of Bali, not those we usually see in Kuta, Legian, etc.

Darius, a good friend since childhood happens to manage a hotel in Balian Beach called "PONDOK PITAYA". He invited us to stay at his place. So we thought why not...it's about 2-hour drive (with traffic time included) from Ngurah Rai airport with great scenic views. 

But boy...if I was impressed then...the moment we arrived at Pondok Pitaya I couldn't stop saying "omg...wow". It's (honestly) nothing like the photos posted on their website...it was WAY MORE BEAUTIFUL in real life!!! It's located right at the end of the of the road, touches the Balian Beach...so you get to eat (delicious & HEALTHY) food in their restaurant with killer view of the sea (and cool surfers)...as well as staying in beautiful wooden houses with rooftops rooms where you can stargaze, or staying at the River Suite where you have little ponds, garden and passionfruit growing on your porch. It was SO BEAUTIFUL and PEACEFUL! 

Darius recommended the River Suite and we fell in love at first sight. The room was simple, but it's just so clean, smells good, sweet, homey, cozy and got all the necessary (strategically positioned) ports to plug your electrical stuff as well as air conditioner just in case the weather gets too hot or humid. The room looks more like a little hut and made of boat woods. It's strong and sturdy but apparently it can float on water (in case of flood or tsunami, knock on wood). Anyway, we felt home. The room also feature orthopaedic bed, which again for a pregnant woman with bad back like myself, is very very helpful!

Everyone in Balian seems to know each other well, you will feel like you're actually part of the village community. We ended up changing our itinerary so that on the last day we could come back to Balian. Staffs and services are great, the place is filled with beautiful souls! And did I mention the massage???? This lady named Iluh, gave me a prenatal massage on the bale-bale next to the beach and honestly, it was the "massage of my life". So therapeutic for the body and the soul. Pondok Pitaya also provides yoga classes, taught by this beautiful kind lady named Bianca. If you feel like morning walk around the villages, you can ask her to show you the way....I did and she showed me this peaceful secluded beach nearby, it was worth it!!
 
When you're there don't forget to try the in-house food and their homemade apple cider "JITU". There are various menu, and Vegetarian friendly. Oh and one last thing...MUST DO hiking + waterfall tour! Went to enjoyed this secluded Blah Mantung waterfall, and it was just so serene and breathtaking, all to ourselves!! If you're a coffee fan, you could also visit the little LUWAK COFFEE factory in Pupuan and do some coffee tasting, as well as drink their herbal teas.

Overall, my husband and I truly recommended this place. It is far from the hustle and bustle of the "modern Bali", but it is worth it, especially if your main purpose of going to Bali is to relax. There are no sellers around the beach so don't worry about being bothered while you sunbathe.

Lastly, thank you very much Pondok Pitaya for giving us the experience of our life...thank you for reminding us again the real beautiful face of Bali.

text:
This is a great place to go. It's got everything you could want from a holiday in Bali, without the crowds.

The hotel and its amenities (restaurant, pool, gardens, yoga studio) hold absolute prime beachfront position that cannot be beaten.  

I think that a real standout is their staff.  Every single one of them is always smiling and happy.  It's amazing, they are genuinely just happy people who will always greet you with warmth and kindness. They all speak very good English, and nothing is too much trouble. 

Beachfront rooms are traditional Indonesian in style, spacious, clean and have fans - more than enough because you have the sea breeze keeping you cool and comfortable.  There are some brand new air conditioned rooms out the back too, they look really nice.  

Restaurant has a chilled vibe, looking straight out onto the surf, with really good food - extensive menu selection of Indonesian and western food. 

Pool that overlooks the surf, with plenty of sunloungers and shade. 

New yoga studio overlooking the beach is pretty cool.  Two classes per day, or you can just go in there anytime and do your thing.  Sprawling, well kept gardens and grass area, with some huts that are perfect for chilling out in and watching the ocean.

Balian is a cool little surf town, like stepping back in time, but in a very good way. Away from the maddening crowds and ridiculous over-development and hype of Kuta, Seminyak, Canggu etc, it is one of the last slices of real paradise in Bali.  Well worth the couple of hours drive to come up. It's a very chilled village, not the place if you want loud night-time entertainment into the small hours of the morning, this is a place to relax, slow down and enjoy life

There is a really good, consistent wave right out the front of Pondok Pitaya. Balian is a semi-secret spot, which is a good thing, because it means less crowds and more chilled vibes. Just don't go telling everyone about it!

Make sure you catch a Balian sunset sitting at the restaraunt or the pool with Bintang in hand.  It's something to behold.

Many people come back to Pondok Pitaya year after year.  Once you have been here, it's not hard to see why.  You'll probably end up as one of them!

text:
I stayed at a bungalow in Pondok Pitaya hotel for 10 days over Dec - Jan period. The bungalow was built in a traditional style which was very charming, it was a clean and cool place surrounded by a beautiful garden.  The double bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was clean and had a hot shower.

I had a few meals at the hotel restaurant which has a good selection of Indonesian and western meals on the menu, they were of high quality and were delicious.  I would highly recommend the yellow curry and a veggie wrap.  The fresh fruit juices were also fantastic and I particularly enjoyed the watermelon juice with lime.

There are a variety of activities on offer, surfing is always an option and if you're not a surfer you can take yoga classes or sunbath by the pool among other activities.  The massages offered through the hotel were very good ( I've had 4 from 3 different masseuses!).  The experience of having the massages at a gazebo by the beach was truly magnificent.  There are also beach walks to different bays and a night market to explore with various local food options.

If you're looking for a real holiday out of the hustle and bustle of Denpasar, I would highly recommend Pondok Pitaya, it is in a tranquil little village with a friendly community feel, the staff at the hotel were wonderful and they go out of their way to make sure you're comfortable and at ease.

text:
My boyfriend and I have been to Balian in either June/July/August for the last four years and stayed at Pondok Pitaya every time. We can't go to Bali without going up to Balian because the waves are so fun and our whole experience there is always amazing.  Pondok Pitaya is hands down the best accommodation in terms of location; you can see the surf from your window, as well as when you're in the pool or eating breakfast. Although the price reflects this (we have noticed the prices have gone up each year), it is still not an expensive place (and I'm a student!) and definitely worth what you pay...especially when it's a matter of $10 or so extra compared to other places. The rooms are spacious with large beds and a nice stone bathroom. The one annoying thing we found was the dimness of light; I can't remember having this problem in previous years so maybe it was just the bulb running out, but we had to use a phone torch a lot of the time. 
Each room has it's own little porch which was great after coming back from a surf; dumping our boards and hanging out all our wet stuff before feasting. The food at this hotel is fine however check out Deki's warung which has really nice food and is just up the hill overlooking the water so has a great view too, and Pondok Pisces has amazing banana pancakes! If you walk in to town between 5:30-7 pm (I could be wrong about this time; best to check with someone else) there are local markets which have really cheap, delicious food. 
I've never stayed with a group here but I remember being shown the wooden house/hut that groups stay in and it was awesome! Also I'm not sure if the yoga is a new thing to the hotel but I have never noticed it or been told about it, I'm definitely keen to give it a shot next time I come up though :) 
The atmosphere at Pondok Pitaya is great, everyone is really friendly (both staff and visitors) and always smiling. The music they play is generally pretty good (apart from one night when hectic club music was being played) but the rest of the time made up for that! One night an Aussie dude that lives in Balian (I forgot your name sorry!) played live music which was amazing!

I would definitely recommend (and have recommended) Pondok Pitaya and Balian in general to anyone! Its a great place and it would be extremely hard to go there and not have an amazing time.

text:
This place has a lot going for it. Location right on the beach. Charming, clean rooms with a 1950s feel to them. Modern, funky bathrooms with a view across the fields while you take a (warm) shower. And a lovely pool right on the edge of the sand. The mosquito nets are robust and red. The breeze through the room when the doors are open is cooling and welcome.

Surfers are catered for with racks for their boards. Yoga is on offer in mornings in wonderful pavillions overlooking the crashing surf.

My main issue with this property in the bar / restaurant attached. It's an integral part of the place and so does have a big impact. The food quality was consistently poor (nasi goreng without an egg??); the music was bad (awful fake-reggae-pop or cover versions of Adele); and someone had added a rope of flashing rope of coloured LEDs. It is such a shame as the furniture, position and overall feel are really something special. This is why those in the know take a few steps down onto the black sand beach and head to the simple little place on the rocks to the right to have their sunset beer and feed.

I really like this place and they seem to be trying really hard to make a go of it. My advice - sort out the bar / restaurant (especially the music which made me seek out another place to have my beers); find a way to have front of rooms open to the breeze at night (perhaps louvre windows?); chill out a little and decide if you want to be a surfer place or a yoga place. At the moment its kind of neither with a bit of naff Kuta thrown in.

text: We stayed at the Pondok Pitaya for four nights as part of our journey around most of the island.  We had booked the Joglo Room and it provided a spacious and relaxing natural retreat for my husband and myself and another couple we were travelling with. The Joglo has hot water (albeit temperamental at times), fan-cooled rooms, a beautiful Balinese interior, spare day beds and an amazing ocean-front view. It is very open and not at all sound proof, so you would need to stay there with family or very close friends. The Pondok Pitaya restaurant was generally good value as were the others doted along the main entry.  The Garden Cafe was a nice place to eat but be prepared for long waits at dinner time.  Not that this bothered us, as once it gets dark in Pondok Pitaya, there isn't an awful lot to do.  But that is part of the appeal of Balian; it is quiet, basic and secluded, free from the hustle and bustle of other parts of Bali. During the day the men enjoyed the close proximity of the surf and my friend and I read, swum in the lovely pool and explored the hill and beyond.  I would recommend Pondok Pitaya to anyone who isn't looking for high rise resort accomodation and loves the surf.  It is a beautiful and unspoilt part of Bali.

text:
This is just a review of the restaurant at Pondok Pitaya, as we have a home in the area and no need for accommodation. We are expats who built our home off Balian Beach about 16 years ago; at that time, other than the nearby bus stop Soka Indah (which has great Nasi Goreng fyi), there were only a few restaurants (one of which is close by to Pondok Pitaya--Gaja Minah; fabulous French/Indonesian food and good wine choices).

Today the area is becoming well known for its surfing and several B&B's have sprung up,along with accompanying restaurants to our delight. There are several little surfer restaurants on this beach now and by far, our favorite two are Pondok Pitaya and Pondok Pisces. Both of these restaurants are usually packed (during high season you might even want to call to make a reservation, although if you are not in a hurry, you can hang out at the beach until there is an available table).  

We love going to Pondok Pitaya to eat, no matter breakfast, lunch or dinner. To start with, the restaurant is right off the beach and the view is stunning.  You can get acceptable wi-fi (a one time fee of Rupiah 50,000 allows you to get their wi-fi access for a good duration of time--we recently went daily for over two weeks with the same access password), so you can get online, eat and drink, all while enjoying a panoramic oceanfront view. 

The menu is really good comfort/diner-style food. The chicken wings are to die for (and come with chunky, crispy fries with just the right amount of salt), the hamburgers are very satisfying (one of the only restaurants in the area to serve them so even more satisfying to have access to them!),  guacamole/bean dip w/chips are great (avocados are seasonal...), the burritos very filling (and high on the carb side if you are a surfer who needs the calories--a bit much for a couch potato...), the fresh fruit smoothies are refreshing, the iced ginger tea is powerful (try it w/o sugar if you really want a kick...), and the BBQ whatever is always fantastic (although a few times the BBQ itself has been broken, so ask ahead of time). There is almost always daily fresh fish and of course a variety of local soups/noodles/rice/curry dishes.  

As for drinks, Bintang beer is always available (and a safe choice). I wouldn't trust ordering cocktails here with vodka/gin, etc. as the brands used are likely also to be local (watchout for the hangover...). Sometimes wine by the glass is available and there are actually a couple of bearable local (Australian joint ventures) wines...they are great about asking to just try a sip first. We bring our own wine and there is no corkage charge (yet...let's hope the place doesnt' become TOO popular so this and other fab oceanfront perks disappear or are charged for....). 

Finally, the staff is very friendly  and as one person has mentioned, reactive. However, they are quick to provide service once you do approach them. Considering you are still out in the middle of relative nowhere, this is a fantastic little beachfront restaurant.
title: Fab comfort food on the beach!
